doc.field: Upper House (Bundesrat) agrees to new rules for refugees

The Upper House (Bundesrat) has given its consent to a whole raft of new laws. If someone applies for asylum and there is proof they have done so in order to obtain benefits, they will have their benefits cut drastically. This is targeted against new refugees getting into Germany in order to be on the social welfare benefit. The new rule would also apply to applicants who have been turned down but try to foil deportation orders by destroying their identification papers. There are, however, exceptions, for example for foreigners who are allowed to stay for the time being.
Upper House (Bundesrat) wants preliminary ban on all nuclear shipments

The Upper House (Bundesrat) has asked for a stop to all nuclear shipments. This is to be in force until the problems of contaminated transport containers have been completely clarified. Federal Environment Minister Merkel said that a total ban of all shipments was out of the question.
Upper House (Bundesrat) wants same-sex relationships to become official
The Upper House (Bundesrat) furthermore asked federal government to stop discriminating against same-sex relationships, advocating so-called 'registered relationships/partnerships'.
Upper House (Bundesrat) agrees to new rules for savings'/tax-exemptions

The Upper House (Bundesrat) also agreed to a compromise as far as workers' investments/savings were concerned. In the future, workers may save significantly higher amounts, and get tax-exemptions for them.
Mr Geissler warns against electioneering using policies against foreigners

CDU politician Geissler warned the ruling CDU/CSU parties against using policies against foreigners for election purposes. This would only raise a lot of hackles without achieving a thing, and distract from the real issues, according to an interview with the Berlin newspaper BERLINER MORGENPOST. And this would also be true for all the others who currently were pushing for stricter policies in this area. There should rather be a global concept how to integrate foreign residents in Germany. At the same time, poverty and civil war in many foreigners' home countries should be fought (sic!), according to Mr Geissler.
Berlin begins large-scale deportation

The churches demonstrate against an impending large-scale deportation, claiming that some 100 Bosnian refugees have been detained violating their human rights. Allegedly the round-up also covered sick people. Berlin's Interior Ministry has confirmed that 94 refugees would be forcibly removed and flown to Bosnia tonight. According to the Minister, this was also to meant as a hint for some 20,000 more Bosnians in Berlin to start packing.
Mr Herzog won't rule out running a second time

President Herzog apparently won't rule out running for the office a second time, though he would only tell after the elections. A spokesperson said that nothing had been finalised yet. So far Mr Herzog had always claimed that running for the office a second time would be out of the question. Allegedly CDU/CSU-politicians had urged him to run a second time, to make sure there would not be an SPD president.
Polls on ability of Greens to join government

More than two thirds of the population think the Greens are unable to govern, according to market researcher FORSA. Only few people can handle the Greens' extremist proposals, such as a general speed-limit for cars and raising the price of petrol to 5 marks/litre. Most of the people interviewed even thought that these concepts could jeopardise the Greens' getting into parliament
Cavalese pilots will be court-martialled

Two US-fighterpilots who have caused the Cavalese accident in February when their plane severed a cable-car's cable, will be court-martialled in the US, and that's final. Both pilots will have to answer charges of manslaughter, causing damage to property and breaking regulations, according to the Chief Commander. When the cable-car's gondola fell to the ground, 20 tourists (some from Germany) died on impact.
Corruption racket in Dortmund and Bochum

Police have uncovered a corruption-racket in the public service. Public servants working at the municipal purchasing departments in Dortmund and Bochum had taken bribes for years. The public prosecutor is investigating 18 public servants and 23 companies. The state of North-Rhine/Westphalia would have been hurt to the tune of several million marks.
